user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of uh_cb:
```c
static void
uh_cb (void *cls,
       struct MHD_Connection *connection,
       void *req_cls,
       const char *extra_in,
       size_t extra_in_size,
       MHD_socket sock,
       struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh)
{
  struct MyData *md;
  pthread_t pt;
  (void) cls;         /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) connection;  /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) req_cls;     /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  md = malloc (sizeof (struct MyData));
  if (NULL == md)
    abort ();
  memset (md, 0, sizeof (struct MyData));
  if (0 != extra_in_size)
  {
    md->extra_in = malloc (extra_in_size);
    if (NULL == md->extra_in)
      abort ();
    memcpy (md->extra_in,
            extra_in,
            extra_in_size);
  }
  md->extra_in_size = extra_in_size;
  md->sock = sock;
  md->urh = urh;
  if (0 != pthread_create (&pt,
                           NULL,
                           &run_usock,
                           md))
    abort ();
  /* Note that by detaching like this we make it impossible to ensure
     a clean shutdown, as the we stop the daemon even if a worker thread
     is still running. Alas, this is a simple example... */
  pthread_detach (pt);

  /* This callback must return as soon as possible. */

  /* Data forwarding to "upgraded" socket will be started
   * after return from this callback. */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I did not find any code fragments that are strictly unreachable (i.e. there is no program point that can never be executed on any possible control-flow path). Reasoning: 

- The abort() calls appear only inside conditional branches (malloc or malloc for md->extra_in or pthread_create failure). Because those calls are conditional, the code following those branches is not globally unreachable — execution reaches those later statements when the conditions are false (allocation succeeds, pthread_create succeeds). The presence of calls that do not return on some paths does not by itself create unreachable code elsewhere.

- The if (0 != extra_in_size) block is conditional but reachable when extra_in_size != 0; the memcpy inside it is reachable in that case. When extra_in_size == 0 the block is simply skipped, which is normal conditional flow, not unreachable code.

- There are no unconditional returns, infinite loops, gotos, or other constructs that would make subsequent statements impossible to reach.

- The (void) casts on unused parameters are not executable statements that could be unreachable; they are deliberate to silence warnings.

Therefore no fragment in the provided function is strictly unreachable and none require investigation under MISRA C:2023 Rule 2.1 for unreachable code. (Note: other issues such as potential runtime errors, resource-management, or conformity to other MISRA rules were not considered here.)
